channel.title: Latest PHMSA Hazardous Materials Incident Reports
channel.description: The latest Form 5800.1 hazardous material reports submitted to the Department of Transportation and posted online by the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration.

item.title: Report I-2024060052
item.description:
Report I-2024060052

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-20T00:36:44+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-04-25
  • City: MILLINGTON
  • State: MD
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: EAST PENN LOGISTICS LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 166135
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: An East Penn Logistics, LLC driver was on Cypress Road Maryland, Rt 291, heading towards the Maryland / Delaware line. While checking in his mirrors he drifted right, went off the road into a ditch and tried to recover back onto the road and over corrected and ended in a roll over onto the driver's side. The driver was treated for minor injuries. The local Police responded to the scene. They called a local towing company to assist in the clean up and the towing of the truck. The Maryland Department of Environment also responded to the call. By the time they arrived, the incident was mostly cleaned up. They were happy with the clean up and no further action to be done via the MD EPA for clean up. The truck and batteries were towed back to Phillips Garage in Sudlersville, MD. The driver returned the next day to help repalletize and package the scrap batteries for shipping back to East Penn Manufacturing, Lyons Station for proper disposal of the batteries at our secondary lead smelter.

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: While conducting arrival inspection on an Arkema railcar (Telx73272) and noticed some product on the side of the railcar. While on top of the car he found product on the side of the housing and immediately notified the Ops Manager. Emergency response contractor, Hepaco, was dispatched to evaluate car issue. During their assessment, they discovered the flange gasket had failed and needed to be replaced.

item.title: Report I-2024070005
item.description:
Report I-2024070005

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-20T00:36:44+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-07
  • City: AUBURN
  • State: MA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ROSS EXPRESS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: The freight was not secured in the trailer coming from Pitt Ohio with a trailer seal on the door. As the trailer was moving to Ross/Auburn, MA terminal the freight shifted and 1 box of 6 boxes shift, broke open causing 4 cans to be damaged as cans of paint leaked in the trailer. The paint only leaked in the yard when the doors were opened. No paint reached any drains. Paint cleanup was performed after it was determined what the proper HM clean up procedure needed to be followed to protect Ross employees. A dock employee then took the damaged box of paint off the pallet in the trailer. The damaged- 1 box/4- 1 gallon cans and cleaning materials used for cleanup were placed in a recovery drum for disposal.

item.title: Report E-2024070465
item.description:
Report E-2024070465

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-19T18:15:23+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-17
  • City: ST PETERS
  • State: MO
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: DAYTON FREIGHT LINES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Dayton Freight personnel observed approximately two (2) gallons of material released from one (1) 5-gallon metal pail due to a pin sized puncture. The released material impacted the trailer floor. Dayton Freight personnel deployed granular absorbents to the impacted area and containerized the spent absorbents into one (1) 5-gallon metal pail. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location. The generated waste will remain onsite for Dayton Freight’s contracted hazardous waste vendor to coordinate disposal.

item.title: Report E-2024070419
item.description:
Report E-2024070419

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-19T18:15:23+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-16
  • City: FORT WORTH
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 4500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal LFW experienced a UN1992 19122 Lacquer Thinner Fast release from a 5-gallon metal pail. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 1 gallon of product released to a 3’ x 3’ area of the concrete dock floor. The release was due to the pail falling off of the pallet as a result of improper loading. Absorbents were deployed and worked into the impacted area. The impacted absorbents and damaged pail were then collected into a 55-gallon metal drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

The cap on the 55-gallon poly drum was hand tightened and shipped on to the consignee. The released material impacted the trailer floor. Dayton Freight personnel cleaned the impacted area and cleanup debris was containerized into one (1) 25-gallon poly drum. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location.   • Description: On July 12, 2024, three (3) 2-gallon containers of UN1760 were crushed in transit and released approximately five (5) gallons of product to the concrete surfaces of the loading dock. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from First Call Environmental (FCE) to remediate the impacted site. The crew utilized absorbents and hand tools to remediate the site. All impacted materials were contained in six (6) 55-gallon drums for disposal.

item.description:
Report E-2024070396

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-12
  • City: KANSAS CITY

  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On July 12, 2024, one (1) 55-gallon drum of UN1824 was punctured in transit by other freight and released approximately thirty (30) gallons of product to the trailer interior and pavement beneath. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Environmental Works, Inc. (EWI) to remediate the impacted site. EWI personnel placed the damaged 55-gallon drum into one (1) 95-gallon poly overpack. Crews deployed neutralizing, granular absorbents to the impacted trailer floor and asphalt and swept them up with hand tools. Two (2) 55-gallon drums of neutralized product and any cleanup debris, and the one (1) 95-gallon overpack of the damaged drum were staged onsite for disposal.

  • Description: On July 11, 2024, one (1) 55-gallon drum of UN3266 was punctured by a nail and released approximately two (2) cups of product to the trailer interior. HES personnel deployed soda ash to the UN3266-impacted trailer and swept them in with hand tools. All soda ash and the damaged drum were placed into one (1) 85-gallon drum for disposal.

  • Description: RESPONDER RESPONDEDED TO LEAKER AT DOOR 18 WITH ALL PPE FOLLOWED THE DECISION TREE FOLLOWED THE PROCEDURE THE PACKAGE WAS SITTING UPRIGHT IN THE TRAILER WITH SMALL WET SPOT IN BOTTOM CORNER OF THE BOX THERE WAS NO OTHER VISIBLE DAMAGE. THE PACKAGE WAS NEUTRALIZED WITH SODIUM BICARBONATE AND THEN ABSORBED WITH ZEP ZORBANT.

item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-19T18:15:23+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-06-29
  • City: BROCKWAY
  • State: PA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: CLI TRANSPORT, LP
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Our tanker vehicle loaded full with 87 Gasoline was struck by another vehicle. Our trailer required to be towed. Before it was towed the damaged trailer was emptied by a third party company with a pumping truck, into an empty secondary tanker we had brought onto location. In the events of the pumping truck transferring the product, the pumping company did not verify that all of the product was transferred from one tank of the damaged truck to the corresponding tank of the new truck. In doing so, our 1100 gallon tank was overfilled and 20 gallons of gasoline was pushed out of the vapor recovery line on our trailer. The third party company used absorbent mats, brooms, absorbent socks, and clean up powder to mitigate the effects of the release.

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: New England Disposal Technologies was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractor’s arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted a 2ft-by-4ft area of the trailer floor and a 1ft-by-3ft area of concrete underneath the trailer and estimated that eight (8) cups of material was released due to the valve being semi open. New England Disposal Technologies personnel neutralized the impacted areas and deployed absorbents. The remaining material in the leaking tote was transferred to a new tote. The leaking tote and recovered material were cut up and containerized into three (3) 55-gallon poly drums for disposal.

  • Description: Clean Harbors was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractor’s arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted a 10ft-by-10ft area of the trailer floor and a 10ft-by-10ft area of the concrete dock floor and estimated that thirty (30) gallons of material was released due improper packaging. Clean Harbors personnel deployed absorbents and then swept up the released material. The damaged drums were overpacked into three (3) 95-gallon poly drums. The recovered material and spent absorbents were placed into three (3) 55-gallon metal drums and two (2) 30-gallon poly drums and were staged onsite at the terminal prior to the contractor demobilization.

  • Description: It was reported that 1- pound of Phycomycin SCP released from one (1) 50-pound plastic bag due to being ripped by a sharp piece of wood from the pallet. ERTS reviewed the SDS with the terminal and it was determined a contractor would be dispatched to assist with cleanup. Clean Harbors was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractor’s arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted a 2ft-by-2ft area of the concrete dock floor and estimated that one (1) pound of material was released due to a bag being punctured by a sharp piece of wood from a pallet. Clean Harbors personnel swept up the released material. The damaged bag and recovered material were placed into two (2) 55-gallon poly drums and was staged onsite at the terminal prior to the contractor demobilization

  • Hazmat Injuries: 0

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO- XDE contacted ERTS regarding a leaking 250-gallon metal tote containing hazardous product, Zinc Octoate 8%. A Contractor discovered that the lid to the tote was loose and likely the cause of the release. It was estimated that 5-gallons of product spilled from the lid impacting the metal tote itself, the wooden trailer floor, and the steel grate on trailer floor. The total impact are was estimated to be 6’x6’. The Contractor was able to tighten the lid and perform a slosh test confirming that adjustments made to the lid were successful and the tote is in proper working order to ship on to the Consignee. One 55-gallon DM was generated for waste disposal containing impacted cardboard, PPE, and absorbent pads/rags. No storm-drains, waterways, or soil were involved in this incident

  • Description: It was reported that approximately 100-gallons of Sulfuric acid released from one (1) 275-gallon tote onto the trailer floor and asphalt underneath the trailer. The Tote was punctured on the bottom by a forklift during unloading, releasing to the trailer interior and onto the dock and parking lot. ERTS dispatched Hepaco to the site to assist with clean up. The contractor arrived on-site and confirmed the product affected a 20’x4’ area on the trailer floor and underneath the trailer floor. The contractor collected and containerized the Dilute Sulfuric Acid (35%) and all clean-up debris into six (6) 55-gallon drums and one (1) 275-gallon tote. All waste was stored onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: According to the information obtained, the following occurred. While unloading, one 2,450Ib tote was discovered leaking. Area was isolated and contractor was dispatched. GrayMar Environmental responded to perform the cleanup. Upon arrival on site, GrayMar Environmental inspected the leaking tote and determined the cap was faulty, which resulted in the release of approximately 0.5 gallon of product. Free product released to trailer floor and dock at customer location. GrayMar Environmental used absorbent material and rags to wipe the area clean, and transferred the leaking tote into a recovery tote to be sent on to the consignee. One 55-gallon drum of spent absorbent and cleanup debris was generated during the cleanup. Product was contained to an impervious surface and did not impact soil or threaten to impact state waters. There were no injuries or exposures reported.

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: According to the information obtained, the following occurred. While reversing into dock area at PepsiCo facility, vehicle struck another truck in lot, which damaged the saddle tank. Approximately 20 gallons of Diesel fuel were released to the asphalt surface and a minimal amount migrated to the nearby storm drain. PepsiCo personnel contained the release, and ACT Environmental was dispatched to perform the cleanup. Upon arrival on site, ACT Environmental applied absorbent material to the affected asphalt and inspected the nearby storm drain. Absorbent pads were utilized within storm drain catch basin to soak free product, and no further residual remained. Product was contained to the storm drain catch basin and did not migrate through drainage system. All spent absorbent material and pads were recovered and containerized into one 55-gallon drum, pending disposal in accordance with local, state, and federal regulations. There were no injuries or exposures reported.

  • Description: According to the information obtained, the following occurred. During delivery, the vent line failed, which resulted in the release of approximately 50 gallons of gasoline to the asphalt parking lot and nearby storm drain. The Local Fire Department responded to assess and applied absorbent material to contain the release. First Call Environmental was dispatched to perform the cleanup. Upon arrival on site, First Call Environmental applied additional absorbent material, which was worked in and recovered. First Call Environmental utilized a drum vacuum to recover the free product from the storm drain catch basin, and confirmed product was contained to catch basin and did not migrate through the sewer system. Two 55-gallon drums of spent absorbent material were generated during the cleanup. There was no impact to soils or threat to state waters. There were no injuries or exposures reported.

  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: On Thursday, 05/02/2024, at approximately 5:25am ET. Standard Petroleum's driver was ' traveling on the 1-95 - southbound in the right lane (of3). As Standard Petroleum's driver approached exit 14 on 1-95 southbound, a black Chevy Camaro struck Standard Petroleum's upper right side as the Camaro driver crossed a solid white line when it merged into traffic. After striking Standard Petroleum's vehicle, the Camaro then struck a trailer traveling parallel to Standard Petroleum m the middle lane, which caused the trailer to strike Standard Petroleum's vehicle. The cause of the failure is still being investigated; however, it is Standard Petroleum s understanding that the trailer struck Standard Petroleum's fuel tank which caused a fuel leak. Since the investigation is ongoing, Standard Petroleum is not able to describe the package failure with specificity at this time. ?nee Standard Petroleum's driver discovered the fuel leak, he immediately called 911 and notified Stand ard Petroleum dispatch of the incident. It is Standard Petroleum's unders!anding that either DEEP or Connecticut State Police notified Standard Republic, who is an environmental first responder for the State of Connecticut, to remedy the fuel leak.

  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal BCO experienced a UN2924 Silquest A-1101 Silane release from a 330-gallon metal tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 2 ounces of product released to the metal tote body only. The plug on the top of the tote was missing which caused the release. The hole was plugged and a slosh test was completed which determined there would be no further release. The tote was wiped down, confirmed neutral, and confirmed secured for shipment on. The impacted pads and PPE were placed into a 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

The material in the tanker started to get hot and run out of the dome and onto the ground. 1 gallon of material leaked into secondary containment and was cleaned up in house. The cause of the spill was that the tanker was overfilled.

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-18T15:13:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-12
  • City: CHARLOTTE
  • State: NC
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ROADRUNNER TRANSPORTATION SERVICES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 7000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On July 12, 2024, at 0337 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Roadrunner personnel in Charlotte, North Carolina regarding the release of Callus Remover Eucamint. Contractors were dispatched to the site to perform all onsite clean-up activities. Upon arrival, contractors confirmed the release of 55 gallons of Callus Remover Eucamint (UN1814, 8, II) from (1) 55-gallon DF. The release was caused by a load shift and contained to pallets and a 6ft x 12ft area on the trailer floor. The load shift also damaged 2 more drums containing the same product, but without release. Contractors placed all 3 damaged drums into overpacks, then neutralized and cleaned the release using absorbents and the proper PPE. All waste was containerized in (3) 55-gallon DF’s and (3) 95-gallon DF’s and staged onsite by contractors for proper disposal.

item.description:
Report E-2024070381

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-18T15:13:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-08
  • City: JEFFERSONVILLE
  • State: GA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: RANGER LANDSTAR INC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 75000
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: On July 8, 2024, at 1745 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Landstar personnel in Jefferson, Georgia regarding the release of Caustic Soda Prills. Contractors were dispatched to the site to perform all onsite clean-up activities. Upon arrival, contractors confirmed the release of Caustic Soda Prills (UN1823, 8, II). The release was caused by a rollover accident that impacted a 360ft x 50ft area of soil and an adjacent concrete lined drainage ditch that contained 635 gallons of free-standing impacted rainwater. Contractors collected the damaged cargo that was still in the trailer, neutralized and collected all free-standing liquid with a vac truck, excavated all impacted soil, then placed seed and straw. Contractors took 635 gallons of impacted rainwater in a vac truck and 11 roll-offs of impacted soil and damaged cargo offsite for proper disposal.

  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On July 8, 2024, one (1) 5-gallon pail of UN1219 was punctured by a faulty pallet and released approximately three (3) gallons of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from E3 Environmental (E3) to remediate the impacted site. The crew placed the damaged jug in one (1) 55-gallon drum. E3 personnel utilized absorbents and hand tools to remediate the site. All impacted debris was collected in one (1) 5-gallon pail.

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-18T15:13:38+00:00

  • City: LOUISVILLE
  • State: KY
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: AIR PACKAGE FROM GERMANY TO THE USA WAS BEING INSPECTED BY USA CBP OFFICIALS WHO DISCOVERED UNDECLARED DANGEROUS GOODS. UPON INSPECTION OF THE CONTENTS DISCOVERED EIGHT BOOKS OF SAFETY MATCHES, FOUR AMICHAUF HEATING KITS CONTAINING SIX COMBUSTIBLE DRY FUEL TABLETS AND ELEVEN ADDITIONAL COMBUSTIBLE DRY FUEL TABLETS. THE COMBUSTIBLE DRY FUEL TABLES ARE REGULATED AS UN1328, HEXAMETHYLENETETRAMINE, 4.1, PG III. THERE ARE NO DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON THE OUTER BOX.

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-18T15:13:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-06-24
  • City: BRATTLEBORO
  • State: VT
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: NEW ENGLAND CENTRAL RAILROAD, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Crew 606 in Brattleboro VT reported a railcar loaded with hydrochloric acid on the adjacent track leaking from the dome. Emergency responders were called to the scene, contained the leak, and released pressure from the tank to stop the leak. Less than 5 gallons leaked out. It was discovered that there was a missing gasket and a defective (worn) gasket. Hepaco did cleanup and repairs, Car Owner (Reagent Chemical) did leak test, and TRC Environmental Consulting did reporting

item.title: Report I-2024070004
item.description:
Report I-2024070004

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-18T15:13:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-06-22
  • City: GRAFTON
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: FREEHOLD CARTAGE INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 2100
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Checking the transfer line, the associate noticed Van 53022 (FCI) was leaking onto the gravel. The associate notified the foreman and pulled the van onto the concrete roadway to get it off the gravel. We assessed the area and then we took the van to the CSF to be offloaded to find the leaking container. About halfway in the trailer we found the drum with a dime size hole in it and the contents had all leaked onto the trailer floor except for approx. 15 gal. We finished unloading the van and we processed the load. We cleaned the trailer floor with floor dry. We also cleaned the TL and the drive. The material that leaked onto the drive stained the concrete. The Transfer Line spill on the gravel was approx. 1 gal. it was contained in a 3 foot radius pot hole so we added floor dry to absorb the material. We took a before and after sample to the lab with the cin. (519142) we used on the drum that leaked. All effected areas have been cleaned. We generated 1 (1/4 Full) Tote. Tote is labeled with a Haz. Label with the info. needed and placed in the on hold area.

item.title: Report E-2024070369
item.description:
Report E-2024070369

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-18T15:13:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-06-20
  • City: ATLANTA
  • State: GA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: HERITAGE TRANSPORT, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 10200
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: The IBC was strapped in the trailer by Heritage Crystal Clean (HCC). Heritage Environmental Services (HES) employees unloaded the trailer at the Heritage Transport (HT) transfer facility. HES employees loosen the load strap which exposed a whole in the body of the IBC. The whole was 1 inch or less in size. The whole was located approximately halfway down the side of the body. HES employees secured and blocked nearby storm drains and contact an emergency response contractor to mitigate the release, transfer the remaining contents of the damaged IBC to a new container, to recover the spilled material, and to containerize absorbent materials. The duration of the release was approximately 90 minutes.

Upon arrival it was noted that the swing bolts were less than tool tight and there was no rim gasket. These issues were immediately corrected by M&M and the leak was stopped.

ERTS reviewed the SDS with the caller and dispatched Hepaco to the site to assist with clean up. Hepaco responded and observed approximately 10-pounds of Cryolite released from the damaged plastic gaylord. The release impacted a 10’X23’ area on the trailer floor. No drains or soil were impacted. Hepaco recovered the Cryolite. Hepaco unloaded the trailer, used simple green rags, wiped down the trailer, freighted, and reloaded the trailer. Hepaco created one 5-gallon poly drum of waste. Hepaco left the waste on-site with the XPO dock manager.

  • Description: At approximately 04:36 AM on 06/09/24 notification was received that the tank car was leaking product (Argon Gas) from the valve on the vent pipe. The car was located on the south end of our Pasadena Yard and we immediately contacted our Haz-Mat Contractor M&M Protection LLC to respond. Upon arrival it was noted that the road isolation valve was in the open position and the gas line closed with the equalizer open as well as the liquid vaporizer sample line was left open. These issues were immediately corrected by M&M and the leak was stopped.

  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal LSL experienced a UN1992 19122 Lacquer Thinner Fast release from (6) 5-gallon metal pails. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 2-gallons of product released to an 8’ x 10’ area of the trailer floor. The lids of the pails seemed to be leaking as a possible result of being stacked and crushed. The damaged pails were collected into an 85-gallon poly drum. Absorbents were then deployed and worked into the impacted area. The impacted absorbents, pads, pallet pieces, and PPE were collected into a 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: On July 5th, during the PM sort a pallet of drums was found leaking. The drums contained UN1263, Paint, 3, III. Two of the drums were damaged at the handles, one was damaged at the top chime, the last one was damaged at the bottom chime. item.title: Report E-2024070299
item.description:
Report E-2024070299

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-17T18:15:41+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-05
  • City: HOUSTON
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On July 5, 2024, one (1) 20-pound box of UN2277 was damaged by a nail and released approximately twenty (20) pounds of product to the truck interior. The monomer product experienced a polymerization reaction and damaged additional containers. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Lone Star Hazmat (LSH) to remediate the impacted site. Crews observed heat and vapor created from the polymerization process and contained and isolated the reacting product. All product was containerized into thirteen (13) 55-gallon vented poly drums. LSH utilized absorbents and hand tools to remediate the impacted trailer and dock. All impacted debris and PPE were collected and containerized into two (2) 55-gallon drums.

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Hazmat was found at door 125 in the load end ready to go to the next load point. The outbound sort manager walked passed it and noticed a very strong odor coming from the box. QA was contacted immediately to inspect the box. I noticed a little wet spot on one of the bottom corners of the package and brought it over to the office in a lined tote for further inspection. The inner drum seamed to have a poor quality closure that caused some of the contents to spill out and make it a little noticeable to the naked eye. Once the package was fully opened, the corrugated liner seamed to be wet also to confirm that the hazmat was damaged and could have possibly been damaged while it was on the vehicle when the driver returned from the pick up but could have dried do to the Acetone & Isopropyl Alcohol ingredient that makes up the product.

  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: DURING THE UNLOAD THE MANAGER NOTICED THAT THE METAL PAIL HAD A DENT BASICALLY ON THE TOP EDGE WHICH WAS CAUSING LIQUID TO LEAK FROM THE PAIL. MANAGER IMMEDIATELY TOOK THE PAIL TO THE HAZMAT CAGE TO SECURE AND VENTILATE IT PROPERLY. I WAS THEN CALLED OVER TO REPACK IT INTO A YELLOW SALVAGE DRUM IN A TIMELY AND SAFE MANNER. APPROXIMATELY 1 LITER LEAKED FROM THE TOP CLOSURE DUE TO A DENT AND PUNCTURE AT THE TOP. WAITING FOR THE DISPOSITION FROM PGH NOW.

  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XTM experienced a UN1500 Sodium Nitrite, Granular Free-Flowing Food Grade release from a 50 pound paper bag. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 3 pounds of product released to a 4' x 4' area of the trailer floor due to a forklift puncture. The damaged bag, released product, and PPE were collected into (2) 55-gallon poly drums. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2024070030
item.description:
Report E-2024070030

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-15T18:15:54+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-01
  • City: SOUTH GATE
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: J. B. HUNT TRANSPORT, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Clean Harbors was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractor’s arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted a 3ft-by-5ft area of the trailer floor and estimated that thirty (30) gallons of material was released due to four (4) crushed 5-gallon plastic pails. The damaged plastic pails were placed into one (1) 30-gallon and one (1) 55-gallon poly drum. Clean Harbors personnel deployed a neutralizer to the impacted area and then used a granular absorbent to gather the spent material. The contractor placed the recovered spent absorbents into one (1) 30-gallon poly drum. One (1) 55-gallon poly drum was generated containing impacted pallet pieces. One (1) additional 15-gallon poly drum was generated for the contractor’s PPE. All waste generated from this response was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location prior to the contractor demobilization. The generated waste will remain onsite for J.B. Hunt contracted hazardous waste vendor to coordinate disposal.

item.title: Report E-2024070218
item.description:
Report E-2024070218

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-15T18:15:54+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-01
  • City: MENOMONEE FALLS
  • State: WI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: VEOLIA ES TECHNICAL SOLUTIONS, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: A Veolia employee was offloading pallets of drums from a trailer at Veolia's 1- day intransit facility in Menomonee Falls, WI. In the process of offloading the trailer, the forks on the forklift extended past the end of the pallet due to it being a smaller size pallet. The employee was unaware of their surroundings and length of forks, allowing the forks to puncture a drum loaded in the truck behind the pallet that was being offloaded. Approximately 1/2 of a gallon of material leaked before the employee was able to secure the drum from leaking any further. The duration of the spill was approximately 30 seconds. The material was then cleaned and the employees reported the spill of material. The drum that was damaged with the forklift was overpacked for safe transportation to the disposal facility.

Upon inspection by BNSF responder, one swing bolt was loose and down, while the other 5 were less than tool-tight. The manway was opened, gasket inspected and manway lid secured properly.

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 9400
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: The KAG Energy, LLC driver was delivering diesel fuel into the customer's storage tank. During the course of the delivery, the connection between the hose adaptor and storage tank became compromised. This caused approximately 100 gallons of diesel fuel to be released. A portion of the spilled diesel fuel was able to impact a nearby storm drain. Hepaco Environmental responded to the scene and handled the remediation.

item.title: Report E-2024070233
item.description:
Report E-2024070233

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-15T18:15:54+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-06-12
  • City: HENDERSON
  • State: CO
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: It was reported that 1-cup of Pliobond 9725 was released due to being punctured. The spill impacted inside the trailer and the concrete dock floor. ERTS dispatched Environmental Works to the site to assist with clean up. Environmental Works personnel deployed oil dri to the impacted areas and containerized the recovered material into one (1) 55-gallon metal drum for disposal.
